utterances: And then Minnesota has a huge refugee population, so I've worked on that issue all over the world as well.

So I think any member of this Senate has to be able to show their foreign relations chops at any moment, whether it was the recent debate we had on Yemen or whether it is trade issues or working with our allies.
So thinking, it's something that you have to do as part of being a senator.
Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota.
Best of luck as you make up your mind.
And thanks for stopping by.
Thank you.
And to circle back to the Facebook part of that interview, we did ask them for a statement.

And they sent us this - quote, ""Facebook's partners don't get to ignore people's privacy settings, and it's wrong to suggest that they do."" Facebook also wrote, ""we know we've got work to do to regain people's trust.
Protecting people's information requires stronger teams, better technology and clearer policies.
And that's where we have been focused for most of 2018.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Here we are, two women, and soon we'll be tackling a topic lots of gals have been talking about lately, the new pill that stops periods entirely.
First, though, men in their 30s are not doing as well financially as their dads did at the same age.
A new study out today by a group of liberal and conservative think tanks says on average the sons make 12 percent less than their fathers.
The median income for a 30-something guy now is about the same as his age, $35,000 a year.
Here to tell us more is one of the authors of the study, John Morton.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks very much.
Thanks for having me.
Well, is this the first time we're seeing the children not doing as well or better than their parents?
We don't know that for sure.

My guess is that during the Depression years and perhaps during other various transitional periods in the American economy there have been generations that have not done as well as their parents, and I'm sure the Depression years would play that out.

It's a little counterintuitive because from all the economic news that I've read over the last three decades, the American economy has actually grown, productivity has increased, so you think incomes would do the same thing.
Well, I think the report says two things.
One is that while male income has been declining over the last 30 years, from 1974 to 2004, family incomes have, in fact, been rising, and I think that an important part of this story as well.
So the stories for families is not - is not as bad as the stories for men.

The subtext, though, is that if you look at family incomes and as they have risen over the last 30 years - and again, these are families with men in their 30s - that rate of growth is only about nine percent over the last 30 years, and that compares to a growth rate of about 32 percent for a previous generation.
So you see declining male incomes from men in their 30s and then growing rates for families, but a slowing growth rate, if you will.
And growing rates because women are working.
That's correct.
Part of that income increase for families has been women - women entering the workforce over the last 30 years.
But could there be also sort of a larger economic force taking place - globalization, for example?
Without a doubt.
Without a doubt.
And I think that one of the things we're going to be doing as part of subsequent research reports is looking at those drivers of mobility.
What in fact is driving these economic trends?
Globalization for sure, workforce participation rates, absolutely, changing family structure is surely part of that story.
You've had a tremendous change in the family structure over the last three or four generations with respect to how many incomes you have per household.
So we'll be looking at all of those issues in much more detail.
This generation, and I'm a part of it, this generation has always complained that we get the table scraps left over from the baby-boomers, that they - they will always do better than we.
They have bigger incomes, they could afford a house; do you think that's part of this?
It could be.
No doubt that there's generational envy.
I'm sure that's part of what's happening here.

You know, I do think, however, that the American dream has been premised on this bedrock principle that each generation will, you know, would do better than the one that came before, and that - that's kind of embedded, I think, in our national psyche.
And so I think one has to wonder what will happen when the perception is that that dream may not be achievable for many Americans today.
What does that mean from a national psyche standpoint?

You know, traditionally I think Americans have been willing to accept fairly large income inequalities within our own society with - because of their belief that they have a shot at making it to the top.
And if the data suggests and if the perception of Americans increasingly is that they don't have a shot at the top, I think that's an important transition in our national attitude.
And what about you, how old are you?
I'm 36 years old.
And?
In this case I fear to say that I've fallen to that 12 percent that has - that has suffered some - some declines from my father's generation.
My father, you know, lived the American dream.
I wouldn't say rags to riches but certainly pulled himself up by his bootstraps and I benefited tremendously from my family's well-being.
And I'm afraid that if I were to take my income at my age, adjusted, inflation adjusted, he would be probably more than 12 percent ahead of where I am now.
You're working for a lowly non-profit.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Certainly not a corporate attorney's salary.
John Morton of the Pew Charitable Trust.
Thanks for joining us.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: Like all who have held this office before me, I have experienced setbacks.
And there are things I would do differently if given the chance.
Yet, I've always acted with the best interest of our country in mind.
I have followed my conscience and done what I thought was right.
You may not agree with some of the tough decisions I have made, but I hope you can agree that I was willing to make the tough decisions.
Tomorrow marks the end of President George Bush's time in office.
He leaves the White House with one of the lowest approval ratings ever, but how will history judge the 43rd president and what will be the Bush legacy?
For more, we have Sherrilyn Ifill, a civil rights lawyer and a law professor at the University of Maryland Law School, and Ron Christie, CEO of Christie Strategies.
He is also a former special assistant to President George W.
Bush.
Welcome, folks.
Let's start with this, Ron.
President Bush faced a lot of challenges both home and abroad during his presidency.
Last week, he shared his views on his performance.
It was mixed, which I don't think comes as a surprise.
We know what the criticisms are going to be, but what victories do you think he had that may become part of his legacy?
Domestic first.
Well, I think he has several meaningful contributions to the American landscape that people will look back and say, thank goodness that President George W.
Bush was in office.

On the domestic front, I think the most important thing that the president was able to accomplish working in a bipartisan manner with the Congress was a piece of legislation called No Child Left Behind.

That bill made sure that we could have a criteria established to determine whether or not our students were learning in schools, whether or not schools are performing adequately, and then use that as a benchmark so that parents could understand what was going on with their children's education.

There have obviously been some hiccups with that bill, but what we've seen over the last several years is the achievement gap has narrowed between African-American and Hispanic students towards white students at a level that we haven't seen before in history.

I think if you also look at what the president tried to do in 2001 and 2003 to stimulate the American economy coming out of a recession when he first took office was to enact a wide-sweeping set of tax cuts that stimulated the American economy and led to a record 50-week growth - job growth - in this country - or I should say 50 months.
So there are several things that he has done on a domestic and an international front that people would look back and say, you know, George W.
Bush had it right when he worked with the Congress to get these landmark achievements accomplished.
Well, Sherrilyn, from the domestic policy perspective, what do you think the president wishes he could do over?
Given what I've seen of George W.
Bush, I don't think he has any regrets.
Here is what I think he should wish he'd done differently.
I think, first of all, the tax cut issue that Ron mentioned is a serious problem.

This is a president who asked us to go into war on two fronts in Afghanistan and Iraq and refused to ask the American people to sacrifice, refused to project out the money that we would need to engage in these undertakings.
And instead, he told us to go shopping, and he insisted on tax cuts, tax cuts that benefitted the wealthy.

And the result of it is that we didn't make those sacrifices, and we ended up on two fronts in very expensive wars, spending billions of dollars, and utterly unprepared for the catastrophic problems with the economy that we've experienced under President Bush's watch.
So I can't imagine that this will be a legacy that will be regarded as a victory or an accomplishment for George W.
Bush.
I think his domestic accomplishments ironically are not ones that he intended.

For example, I think that the problems and the deficiencies in the response to Katrina actually have convinced the American people that we do need government, that the Republican mantra of smaller and smaller government, of Grover Norquist wanting to, you know, make government small enough that he could drown it in the bathtub, that Katrina showed us that we actually need government to do certain important things like preserve infrastructure and be available to respond to the kinds of disasters in a competent way.
And that's the other piece, that competence counts.
You know, this is an administration that regularly derided those who were elitist, that derided education, that derided science, and that focused on the pageantry of feelings and hunches.
And what we saw is that what we really need is competence.
You know, Brownie may be a very affable, nice guy to have a drink with, but he shouldn't have been FEMA director.

And so some of these things that are going to be, I think, part of the Bush legacy are not things that President Bush intended, but are just the consequences of the catastrophic mistakes that he made.
From a foreign policy standpoint, Ron, there is the Iraq war, of course.
But Bush did seem to have some success in Africa, more so than perhaps any U.S.
president before him in terms of his efforts in the battle against AIDS.
One, do you agree with that assessment?
And two, do you think that his work there will help salvage his reputation internationally?
Well, again, I think that history is one that is going to treat the president far more kindly with the ability and retrospection of time than where we see right now.
Obviously, President Truman left office with very low approval ratings.
President Nixon left the office with very low approval ratings.
And over the course of time and after the cause of reflection, I think Americans recognized the important contributions that these presidents had made.
Looking at Africa, I think there's no question.
The president had an initiative called PEPFAR, which is the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief.

And what the president was able to do was to work with the Congress to ensure that not only those who are suffering from HIV/AIDS, but also those who are suffering from malaria were able to get the treatment and able to get the assistance from the United States that they didn't have before.
